thread.title: NWSL title game: Reign FC again falls to FC Kansas City
thread.title_full: NWSL title game: Reign FC again falls to FC Kansas City | The Seattle Times

author: Matt Pentz
title: NWSL title game: Reign FC again falls to FC Kansas City
text:
PORTLAND, Ore. – For more than a year, the Seattle Reign has brooded over its National Women’s Soccer League championship game loss to FC Kansas City .
Thursday night, in front of an announced attendance of 13,264 at Providence Park, with a chance to make amends against that same FCKC team, Seattle instead got hit with a serious case of déjà vu.
Amy Rodriguez scored the game’s only goal in the 78th minute, and though Seattle controlled the tempo for most of the night, it again fell one win shy of the NWSL title as Kansas City repeated as league champions, 1-0.
The bracket had set up perfectly for a Reign team that again finished the regular season in first place by double-digit points. In the semifinals awaited the Washington Spirit, the same team it squeaked past at the same stage last season. Then Kansas City upset Chicago on the road, and the serendipity of a rematch was on.
Most Read Stories Parents of toddler killed in Bellevue to return to India At least 9 killed in Roseburg, Ore., college shooting; gunman dead Man charged with breaking $120K Chihuly sculpture in Tacoma Time running out on Seattle family’s ‘golden ticket’ to landing home Former Seattle Times building now home to thieves, squatters Unlimited Digital Access. $1 for 4 weeks. Seattle dominated the 2014 campaign so thoroughly that it clinched the regular-season title with more than a month to spare. But in the title game, the Reign was upset 2-1 in front of stunned home fans.
Seattle doesn’t get nervous, no matter what the stakes — at least according to star attacker Kim Little. Looseness is in this team’s DNA, and more than one player credits the team’s success to the relaxed locker room vibe that coach Laura Harvey has encouraged.
“Not being arrogant, we just have the belief that we’re good enough to beat any team,” Little said earlier this week. “Just the relaxed nature of our club helps us. We don’t feel the pressure, don’t feel nervous. When we’re relaxed, that’s when we play our best football.”
Blame the stakes, blame two talented teams warily eying each other up, but Thursday’s match was anxious from the start.
Early on, at least there were scoring chances: Rodriguez shook free for a decent look 12 minutes in, then Little fired right into KC goalkeeper Nicole Barnhart’s arms when released on a counterattack. From there on out, though, the teams mostly just poked and prodded.
Reign midfielder Megan Rapinoe smashed a shot off the left post midway through the second half, but otherwise, the game looked destined for added time. 
Then Lauren Holiday found Heather O’Reilly, who hooked in a cross for Rodriguez’ head. Rodriguez’s header caught Seattle goalkeeper Hope Solo leaning.
The Reign pressed, huffing and puffing until the last.
But for the second straight year, Kansas City held on. For the second straight year, Reign bodies sank dejected to the turf as white-shirted opponents screamed in triumph around them.
Matt Pentz: 206-464-3184 or mpentz@seattletimes.com . On Twitter @mattpentz .
